prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for deleting his ex’ contact number in his phone?
Bf and I allow full access to each other’s phones.  I saw his ex in his contacts and asked him why she was still in there.   He said he just hadn’t bothered to remove her yet, but had no intention of contacting her again.  So I deleted her.   He was surprised and asked me why I did that.  I just said if you’re not going to contact her why have her in there.   I can tell he’s bothered, but am I wrong?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who deleted their boyfriend's ex's contact number was in the wrong. The situation is that the couple allows full phone access to each other. The boyfriend said he hadn't removed the ex yet but didn't plan to contact her again. The author then deleted the contact, which surprised him.

Hmm, so the key points here are about privacy and boundaries, even in a relationship where phones are shared. The couple has agreed to full access, so maybe the expectation is that anything on the phone is fair game. But the boyfriend didn't remove the contact himself, which the author took as a sign that he wasn't going to use it anymore. But deleting someone's contact without their permission might be crossing a line. 

Even though they have access, does that mean they can make decisions on each other's behalf? The boyfriend might feel that his personal contacts are his own, even if he's not using them. Maybe the author assumed the right to delete the contact because they thought it was for the best, but respecting each other's autonomy is important. 

Also, communication is a big part of relationships. Instead of deleting the contact, maybe discussing it more and letting the boyfriend handle it himself would have been better. The author's action, while well-intentioned, might have been a breach of trust or respect, even if they had the access to do so. 

So, the answer might be that the author is in the wrong because they didn't respect their boyfriend's personal space and made a decision for him. Even with shared phone access, personal choices like keeping or deleting contacts should be the individual's own.
